channel.title: Changing link letters to words e.g:- /t/ to /kvm/ & /c/ to /kvm
channel.description:
i can see great links nomenclature in discourse but if course if we can make it possible.
for example (1):-
https://forums.whonix.org/t/problem-with-running-whonix-on-fedora-21
can we change /t/ to /kvm/ ? it will be easiest way for referring the forum links.
also example (2):-
https://forums.whonix.org/c/kvm
cant we delete /c/ and make it only /kvm ?
hope to c the answer soon.
thnx

item.title: Changing link letters to words e.g:- /t/ to /kvm/ & /c/ to /kvm
item.dc:creator: TNT_BOM_BOM
item.description:
it seems that this solution is very far away to happen so im going to work on the wiki to change the old forum links to our links.

btw fabricator has many links related to the old forum but i dunno how to fix them while they r reports instead of being a wiki. @Patrick

Read full topic

item.title: Changing link letters to words e.g:- /t/ to /kvm/ & /c/ to /kvm
item.dc:creator: TNT_BOM_BOM
item.description:
done

Discourse Meta

Changing link letter to word e.g:- /t/ to /name of the category & modify or...

hi there , i can see great links nomenclature in discourse. examples:- (1):- support - Discourse Meta instead of putting /c/ it just directly go to /support , or even modifying /c/ to /category/ or …etc. (2):- Discourse Meta instead of /t/ we...

item.title: Changing link letters to words e.g:- /t/ to /kvm/ & /c/ to /kvm
item.dc:creator: Patrick
item.description:
/t/ stands for topic.
/c/ stands for category.

https://forums.whonix.org/c/kvm

This is also that way on https://meta.discourse.org.

You can look through other users of the discourse forum software (http://www.discourse.org/faq/customers/) if any of them changed this.

Read full topic
item.source: Changing link letters to words e.g:- /t/ to /kvm/ & /c/ to /kvm

item.title: Changing link letters to words e.g:- /t/ to /kvm/ & /c/ to /kvm
item.dc:creator: fortasse
item.description:
I don’t see any obvious way to do that in Discourse, but I’ll do some digging. It may also be worthwhile to ask upstream.

Read full topic
